bibl.title: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, June 24, 1928

div1.p: Carter describes the considerable progress on the bibliography and that the Library of Congress staff is helpful. She also asks if Russell has any information about Noguchi's death.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, June 24, 1928

opener.dateline:
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
June 24, 1928.

div1.p:
Just to report another week of intensive work, on the part of
Miss Brown and myself, and of very satisfactory progress. Indeed, I cannot
speak too highly of Miss Brown's devotion, enthusiasm and efficiency.
My one regret, for the past seven days, is that Dr. Frost had to post-
pone his trip to Washington. He hopes, however, to be over sometime
this coming week. The delay in Dr. Frost's arrival does not interfere
with the present progress of the bibliographic work. I shall, however,
be very glad to see Dr. Frost when he comes and shall, of course, prompt-
ly write you of what he says both as to what has been done since I left
the Hopkins and as to what remains to be done.

In the meanwhile with very best wishes, and assuring you that the
work is being pressed to the utmost
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, Laura A. Carter Dr. Frederick F. Russell, Director,
International Health Division,
The Rockefeller Foundation,
61 Broadway, New York, N. Y.
As I wrote you, when I first started work at the Library of Congress,
Dr. Putnam and his staff have been most kind in affording me facilities
for my work. I mention this again as they are constantly surprising me
with new evidences of their thoughtfulness and helpful consideration of
my needs in pushing through so complicated a things as the bibliography
of the History of Yellow Fever.
Speaking of yellow fever, have you heard the details of Noguchi's
death yet? I have heard so many contradictory statements that I should be
grateful to know just how it happened: as I shall ever deplore its occurrence!
L.A.C.
2
P. S. Is it true, as I have been told, that Theodore Hayne, son of
the Health Officer of South Carolina is with your Division? If so,
I congratulate both sides! Father said that Theodore was the best man
of his age whom he had ever seen: fine mind and character: enthusiastic
about his work and with great energy and executive ability in addition to
his intellect.
